name: Iconography
htmlBanner:
Icon

The key goal of our entire visual system is to present information as clearly as possible. Well-executed typography that works within the system creates harmony and balance.

Style.html:
Principle

Product icons are derived from basic geometric shapes and created using a consistent grid system to deliver a unified look and feel. Use these principles as a reference guide when creating additional icons for the system in order to maintain consistency. Our product iconography has two themes; a linear and filled version. Filled versions work well at small sizes in our product experience.

Geometry

We use simple, modern and approachable geometric shapes.

Stroke

We use a bold and precise stroke to reflect connections and emphasize ideas.

Roundness

We use friendly, rounded corners for a distinct look and feel.

Construction

The anatomy of an icon consists of a set of tools, which are used to create new designs.
Geometry
Stroke
Radius
End cap

Geometry

Shape is based on basic geometric shapes—squares, rectangles, circles, triangles.
Combinations of shapes allow for variety and diversity and the foundation of our visual style.

Stroke

Line should reflect connection through the continuity of line. However, there is flexibility to always prioritize legibility over style.
Stroke weight is always consistent and should feel sophisticated. Avoid using varying stroke weights within one composition.

Radius

Radius should be rounded while retaining a recognizable geometry.

End Cap

Terminals are always rounded. Avoid using square end points.

Keyline

All icons will fit within a 32px square box. The icon drawing itself can be smaller than the 32px boundary.
Each frame includes a 3px trim space and key shapes for optical balance. It’s acceptable to go beyond the padding or off the key lines if doing so improves the optical balance of the icon.

Keyshapes

Keyshapes provide template shapes to start and build icons quicker. Library will offer four basics shapes: a circle, square, portrait rectangle, and landscape rectangle.

Styles

Light: 1px
Regular: 1.5px
Bold: 2px
Filled

Stroke Alignment

Centered

SF Alternative

In order to align with iconography on iOS native applications, we have included the SF Symbol variant on iconography using the SF Symbol rather than the custom Momentum icon. Note: Not all Momentum Icons have SF Alternatives. For those that don’t, we use a red box to indicate to designers that no alternative exists. Please request one, if you need one for your iOS feature.

Icon Naming

We have to be intentional in naming and be as forward-thinking as possible. If it’s a metaphor that may have multiple versions.

Icon Size Guide

Light, Regular, Bold, Filled

Usage.html:
Usage Example

You will notice groups of icons emerge within the client, and they will follow a similar approach if possible.

Setting Panel

Stroke

Meeting Panel

Stroke

Size & Weight

When it comes to the correct weight to use for an icon, the main factor to consider is its size (see chart under ‘Our Icon Size/Weight Guide’).

Light

Used mainly for larger icons (>32px) and is 1px in stroke weight

Regular

Used mainly for medium to large icons (>24px) and is 1.5px in stroke weight

Bold

Used mainly for smaller icons (<32px) and is 2px in stroke weight

Filled

Used mainly for smaller icons (<32px), it is also used as an active state for certain icons.

Special Cases

In some cases, where there are two icons in close proximity, we will need to check the weight to see if they match up well. On the left, you can see the arrow looks lighter than the microphone icon.

Badge Variants

Any character within an icon should be legible and of a certain size.
Therefore, we’ve created ‘badge’ variants that meet AX requirements.

DO use badge variants of character icons sized 16px or smaller

DON’T use regular character icons sized 16px or smaller

Color Guidance

The Momentum icons are created with a decisive balance of size, shape, and weight in place. Adding color to the set should be carefully considered and very intentional. Use of color should be used to communicate further information to the user.

General Color

The majority of our icons will come in black or white (theme dependent). Gradients should never be applied to icons.

DO apply black and white colors to icons

DON’T apply gradients to icons

Other Use of Colors

Other colors will be used to further provide information for the user if necessary. Examples of these can be seen here:

Avoid contracting

This indicates that the person should not be contacted.

Possibly available

There is a possibility that the person in question might respond to you.

Unabailable

Very unlikely to get back to you due to being away or busy.

Available

This person should be available to contact or respond to you.

Using Modifiers

Modifiers can be difficult to add to shapes at times, so there are a few tips that can help. Modifiers aren’t fully accessible, so use them sparingly.
A modifier should be a simple addition to the metaphor and is usually tied to an action on a standard icon.

Our modifiers vary between the top or bottom right of the icon. In some cases it will be clearer to place the icon in one over the other. If it does not affect the legibility of the icon, it is best to place this modifier in the bottom right.

Modifier size - For the base icon (32px), all modifiers should fit in a 12px container. Plus modifiers will fit in a 10px container.

Icon Size

Modifier size

32

10

32

12

Lettering in Icons

Please consider if an icon needs text before doing it. Typically an icon containing a letter or letters is very basic in shape (see examples below). It’s a tricky balance to fit letters in. If needing a custom icon, reach out to the momentum iconography team to get help. Because icons are svgs, characters within icons will not be localized. For this reason, consider if the character(s) in the icon are globally understood. If they are not, it’s best to use a graphic icon instead of a text-based icon.

Using Icons in Buttons

1. Icon buttons are typically used for inline actions when there’s no room or when it’s a commonly-seen icon and that simple action doesn’t need to command too much of attention

2. Include a tooltip if some users might not be able to comprehend the meaning of an icon.

3. Icon buttons can take the form and style of the pill buttons and should follow the same hierarchical rule. When applying the tertiary style to icon buttons, make sure to always have a visible container when they’re interacted with. Show background on hover and pressed states to give a clearer visual indication of something that can be interacted.

4. The background shape of an icon button can be circular or rectangular depending on its surrounding elements and placement.
When it’s placed within a compact container such as the bulk action bar or a table row, use the rectangular icon buttons. When it’s not within a compact container, use the circular icon buttons.

Buttons may include an icon after the text label when; it’s a split button that opens a menu it indicates a direction; i.e. the Next button that takes users to the next step

Do’s & Don’ts

Do

Do - Establish importance, this is especially the case for the forefront of the application Do - Double check you are using the correct weight for your icon. You can check this from our chart from section 1 (overview) Do - Check our extensive library to see if we have exisiting icons that cover your need, if so discuss this with the iconography team Do - Raise questions if you find any issues in our current library, whether it is the naming or the use of any icon we currently have

Don’t

Don’t - Simply "Because", really think about the value of using the icon for your specific instance Don’t - If a section of the UI is busy, consider whether using an icon adds to how busy this area looks, and if it really needed Don’t - When text labels are overkill, avoid the use of icons also Don’t - Reuse icons for different purposes without checking if it’s okay first (contact members of the iconography team in this instance)

Overview.html:
Our Icon Size & Weight Guide

Produce icons in three different weights plus filled shape. Be concise and intentional with every stroke to communicate the essence of what’s being represented.

Focus on a single standard base size (32), with four weights—allowing for more scale and visual affordances  (use 1, 1.5, 2 centered stroke)

All icons can scale naturally using SVG or font icon formats.
